explanation:
Reason for inclusion (concise):

- OS_TaskGetId_Impl
  - Called to obtain task_id. Must inspect to know if it has side-effects (modifies objects that could be used as for-loop counters) or contains for-loops that would count toward MISRA analysis.

- OS_ObjectIdGetById
  - Called in the conditional and writes token via output parameter. The MISRA rule treats behavior of functions called in for-statements as part of the loop body; similarly, any side-effects in this call (persistent side effects, modification of objects) are relevant to deciding well-formedness.

- OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit, OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex, OS_ObjectIdConvertToken, OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel
  - Direct callees of OS_ObjectIdGetById. Their implementations may contain for-loops or modify global/state objects or the token; needed to determine whether any loop-related violations originate in this path.

- OS_TaskDetach_Impl
  - Called with &token; may modify token or other global objects or contain for-loops. Its effects are part of OS_TaskExit behavior and must be examined for side-effects on potential loop counters.

- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken
  - Callee of OS_TaskDetach_Impl. Include to inspect deeper side-effects/loops.

- OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete
  - Called to complete deletion; may perform transactions/notifications and contain loops or modify objects that could be loop counters.

- OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish, OS_NotifyEvent
  - Callees of OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete. Needed to examine any loops/side-effects they introduce.

- OS_TaskExit_Impl
  - The implementation-level exit which is documented to never return. It could contain complex control flow or loops (or perform modifications) that are relevant to MISRA analysis of any for-loop that includes a call to OS_TaskExit (or if OS_TaskExit were inlined/expanded in analysis). Must be inspected.

- UT_ExecuteBasicHandler, UT_GetStubEntry, UT_SetHandlerFunction, UT_DefaultStubImpl
  - Listed in the static call graph as possible test/handler code related to OS_TaskExit. If present in builds, these may introduce side-effects/loops; include to be thorough.

- osal_id_t, OS_object_token_t
  - Type definitions for task_id and token. The structure/layout/semantics of OS_object_token_t (and any fields that are shared/global) are needed to know what is being modified by the functions above and whether those modifications could violate the MISRA constraints on loop counters/flags.

- OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, OS_SUCCESS
  - Macros/constants used in the call to OS_ObjectIdGetById. Their values/meanings may affect control flow (e.g., different code paths) and thus whether any called routines execute loops or modify objects relevant to the MISRA rule.

Summary: The MISRA for-loop rule requires considering the behaviour of functions called in loop statements and any side-effects on loop counters/flags. To determine whether OS_TaskExit violates the rule (directly or via functions it invokes), the above direct callees and their immediate callees, plus the involved types and constants, are required so the next analyst can inspect implementations and data-structure semantics for possible persistent side-effects or ill-formed for-loops.
